Reviews/Synopsis
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Please go to the following website for detailed information:
 <a href="
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Painted_Faces" rel="nofollow" target="_NEW">
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Painted_Faces</a>

I first saw this movie at a film festival some years ago. Jackie Chan came personally to share some of his favorite films. I so enjoyed this movie that I have never forgotten its impact on me.
 Knowing that the story is based on the true-life experiences of Jackie and his friends as children under the care and discipline of the Chinese Opera makes it even more exciting to watch. The movie is full of acrobatics, make-up, and wonder.
 It's an intimate portrait of the life of these children and the world they lived, worked, and grew up in.
This film has a depth of character and humility that is all too often not found in todays movies. The performances are endearing all around. Even though Sammo Hung's character is a severe taskmaster, you cannot help feeling for him by the end of the film.
 And the children are a delight from the start. The martial arts sequences are masterfully executed. Moreover, the non-combbative focus of the choreography makes it a great choice for those who may be turned off by more hard core action.
 A good date film, although perhaps a step below Jackie Chan's Canton and Lady Rose in that department.
